Up to 5.8 million kids have long COVID, study says. One mother discusses the "heartbreaking" search for answers.@https://twitter.com/SaraMoniuszko3/15/2024

Amanda Goodhart says her 6-year old son Logan caught COVID multiple times. But even months later, his symptoms didn't get better.

COVID-19, COVID-19 Pandemic, ChildrenRead

to 5.8 million young people have long COVID, according to a recent study \u2014 and parents like Amanda Goodhart are looking for answers.\u00a0She says her 6-year old son Logan caught COVID multiple times. But even months later, his symptoms didn\u0027t get better.\"To see him struggle to stay awake, or crying and saying he doesn\u0027t feel good, it\u0027s heartbreaking, it\u0027s demoralizing, because there\u0027s not a lot of treatment options,\" she told CBS News.\u00a0Study author Dr. Rachel Gross of NYU\u0027s Grossman School of Medicine says one major challenge in tracking the illness is that symptoms can vary.\"Long COVID can look different in different children, that not everybody has the same symptoms and that it can look different depending on when the symptoms start,\" she says.Some common long COVID symptoms in kids include:\u00a0HeadacheLoss of taste and smellBrain fogPainLogan has also been dealing with circulatory and gastrointestinal problems, and he gets tired even from things like standing in line.Adults with long COVID may have these 12 symptoms, study findsDoctors say most children with long COVID recover over several months, but about a third experience symptoms even one year later.\u00a0Goodhart says it\u0027s been frustrating, adding they\u0027ve tried multiple treatments with only moderate improvement.\"It\u0027s terrible, there\u0027s nothing worse than seeing your child go through something you can\u0027t fix,\" she says.The research also shows long COVID can raise the chances of a child developing type 1 diabetes. And it can even be deadly, leading to multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention describes the syndrome as a \"rare but serious condition associated with COVID-19 in which different body parts become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs.\"\"This study was urgently needed because there are so many questions that need to be answered about pediatric long COVID,\" Gross says.The Goodharts hope more attention is given to studying long COVID so more effective treatments can be found.\u00a0","alternativeHeadline":"Millions of kids have long COVID and symptoms can be \"heartbreaking\"","video":{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"VideoObject","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https:\/\/www.cbsnews.com\/video\/millions-of-kids-suffering-from-long-covid-study-finds\/"},"name":"Millions of kids suffering from long COVID, study finds","description":"A recent study estimates millions of children are suffering from long COVID.           <figcaption class="embed__caption-container"><a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/video/millions-of-kids-suffering-from-long-covid-study-finds/" class="embed__headline-link" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="">
          
          <span class="embed__icon">
            <svg viewbox="0 0 32 32" aria-hidden="true"><use xlink:href="#icon-video"></use></svg></span>

          <span class="embed__headline">Millions of kids suffering from long COVID, study finds</span>

          <span class="embed__video-duration">01:38</span>

                      </a>
                  
        
        
              </figcaption></figure><section class="content__body"><p>Up to 5.8 million young people have <span class="link"><a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/long-covid-americans-new-cdc-survey-data/" target="_blank" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="">long COVID</a></span>, according to <a href="https://publications.aap.org/pediatrics/article/153/3/e2023062570/196606/Postacute-Sequelae-of-SARS-CoV-2-in-Children?autologincheck=redirected" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">a recent study</a> — and parents like Amanda Goodhart are looking for answers. </p><p>She says her 6-year old son Logan caught COVID multiple times. But even months later, his symptoms didn't get better.</p><p>"To see him struggle to stay awake, or crying and saying he doesn't feel good, it's heartbreaking, it's demoralizing, because there's not a lot of treatment options," she told CBS News. </p>    <aside class="newsletter_signup ">
              
        

<figure class="embed embed--type-newsletter-widget embed--float-none embed--size-large embed--type-iframe" data-ads='{"wordCount":50}'><div class="embed__content-wrapper">
    <div class="embed__resizer"></div>
    <iframe class="embed__content lazyload" data-src="/embed/newsletters/widget/m40186?v=29ebd300d9a3cd24077d945a46991f72&view=compact#vZVNc%2BM2DIb%2FCkfHjhlTsr5PTde70710M930VG88FAnZnEiihqTscTP%2B7wUlOU7cyx4yPQoAAfDlA%2Bgl0L1TurNB%2BRK0QksIyqCNWZinwSI4KDjit9Btz4VDQ6%2Bt8uFovLcWHPlNy1NwXgTOcPGsup1Po%2BznjlcNyKB0ZoBFwI1TooH7we21%2BYrmv4M4yVYVpJxGEZcUvzit0nBF4ywv4mIVplkaYT0ZJ2mWpCuaxYWgcVUJWuVpShMRy4TVOYbK4MdNhT94C76G5YaTVndqsP88a8zWKrHn0JAdaLODN%2Bd8TwEWhSrOMoq5gcYyBcqLuKKhiLJEhDVkuW9pPvIwVGvuvFoRi2LKVjRMSJiXUVqyJLjpCNW96WbxvpeFddDvoSO2VW5%2FPf4dhO4kN6fXPC8%2Fp0l5e9nza87PUrk5VcqyqEhqTlOecxqGENFChhFl%2BP415JyxivnW3zV3zfSoXOMVGHriNEnuctKqpkE8yLOSluz5AUijux0R%2BqDkglg3yBOx%2FGTviO4A1XB7MEQqKwakyRL8JJvNJtgDVqgMcI%2BUNxCLFrEntTaEd%2FYIxt5dVXo89TBi2jno3Ha2ol%2FopgHhgZ2oK6JUCEhWFGSR0jjlnOa8AFohexDxLM%2FZymNxPXdhSWijO35QZrCk550ElNdHSjgocWlAgn12usfCyq7h4NnwM8N3l4AOjnarHLRoxkEan2KapsHOpt8VGF8QJWjc%2Fsid2Ps63vV9agmj3zon31zAgO1xmBUKf4QKfdiOEiPeecWrTHBG6yTGu68yRqtQCJoVcYjE8DqRcDkw3fqmzGDBzGV4h20sgkYhEEEZTy18M2qnXu9yAVgPRoyPU1nir4%2BuyqCADw13%2BJrt2Bs6R2l8mu1VReHrKMGbB47clcFm6aM2y5kySz1m1BNGR8LoCBi1p7Z3urV04otO7CBJFAvSGZ%2FN8m2Bv0zj7%2Btcb8vNcrM8Ho93c1N3uP0%2BvLC9zPWjl9v6B0fVftw6vsrRVWdMQr6qaBVBPY0pX9WMsqgIwzwO8ywp%2FGFP2vx0H97x9uGafFam%2FHhZZpLX41T9h%2Benp6crHD72wagWtfrTqpkiNbfmnX7hc%2FMMDit9avQgv5ndSFvI1qswipIkSr58SbKC3ccFW8frX%2B%2BlrhDj3bg5WoszD35Lisj%2FHRhL2PhTFPFVAg%2BHN6Vo%2BqUbmgY%2FOuTYbXeXeZ8svN9yPxvdZslfY6y7yYSrFcbtjPaf2c2kJLc%2FDn%2Fz9880Gz9N%2F%2Far0eF0q6H1N4TOL6veaOn3ldG1at7EjmKeJ7z%2B30E5n%2F8F" data-width="auto" data-height="205" frameborder="0" loading="lazy" scrolling="no" data-optanon-category="social" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>
  </div>
</figure>
  </aside>
  <p>Study author Dr. Rachel Gross of NYU's Grossman School of Medicine says one major challenge in tracking the illness is that symptoms can vary.</p><p>"Long COVID can look different in different children, that not everybody has the same symptoms and that it can look different depending on when the symptoms start," she says.</p>

    
<div id="mpu-plus-outstream-middle" data-ad="mpu-plus-outstream-middle" class="ad-mpu-plus-outstream-middle ad-wrapper " data-ad-unit='"mpu-plus-outstream-middle"'>
    </div>
<p>Some common <span class="link"><a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/long-covid-symptoms-nih-study/" target="_blank" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="">long COVID symptoms</a></span> in kids include: </p><ul><li>Headache</li><li>Loss of taste and smell</li><li>Brain fog</li><li>Pain</li></ul><p>Logan has also been dealing with circulatory and gastrointestinal problems, and he gets tired even from things like standing in line.</p><ul><li><span class="link"><a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/long-covid-symptoms-nih-study/" target="_blank" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="">Adults with long COVID may have these 12 symptoms, study finds</a></span></li></ul><p>Doctors say most children with long COVID recover over several months, but about a third experience symptoms even one year later. </p><p>Goodhart says it's been frustrating, adding they've tried multiple treatments with only moderate improvement.</p>

    
    
<div id="leader-plus-inc3" data-ad="leader-plus-inc" class="ad-leader-plus-inc ad-wrapper " data-ad-unit='["leader-plus-inc",3]'>
    </div>
<p>"It's terrible, there's nothing worse than seeing your child go through something you can't fix," she says.</p><p>The research also shows long COVID can raise the chances of a child developing type 1 diabetes. And it can even be deadly, leading to <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/mis/index.html#:~:text=Multisystem%20inflammatory%20syndrome%20(MIS)%20can,%2C%20eyes%2C%20or%20gastrointestinal%20organs." target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener">multisystem inflammatory syndrome</a> in children. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention describes the syndrome as a "rare but serious condition associated with COVID-19 in which different body parts become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs."</p><p>"This study was urgently needed because there are so many questions that need to be answered about pediatric long COVID," Gross says.</p><p>The Goodharts hope more attention is given to studying <span class="link"><a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/long-covid-symptoms-americans-every-day-getting-up-is-a-fight/" target="_blank" data-invalid-url-rewritten-http="">long COVID</a></span> so more effective treatments can be found. </p>

readabilityObject.title: Up to 5.8 million kids have long COVID, study says. One mother discusses the "heartbreaking" search for answers.
readabilityObject.content:
By , Michael George

Edited By Stephen Smith

Updated on: March 15, 2024 / 3:47 PM EDT / CBS News

Up to 5.8 million young people have long COVID, according to a recent study and parents like Amanda Goodhart are looking for answers. 

She says her 6-year old son Logan caught COVID multiple times. But even months later, his symptoms didn't get better.

"To see him struggle to stay awake, or crying and saying he doesn't feel good, it's heartbreaking, it's demoralizing, because there's not a lot of treatment options," she told CBS News. 

Study author Dr. Rachel Gross of NYU's Grossman School of Medicine says one major challenge in tracking the illness is that symptoms can vary.

"Long COVID can look different in different children, that not everybody has the same symptoms and that it can look different depending on when the symptoms start," she says.

Some common long COVID symptoms in kids include: 

  • Headache
  • Loss of taste and smell
  • Brain fog
  • Pain

Logan has also been dealing with circulatory and gastrointestinal problems, and he gets tired even from things like standing in line.

  • Adults with long COVID may have these 12 symptoms, study finds

Doctors say most children with long COVID recover over several months, but about a third experience symptoms even one year later. 

Goodhart says it's been frustrating, adding they've tried multiple treatments with only moderate improvement.

"It's terrible, there's nothing worse than seeing your child go through something you can't fix," she says.

The research also shows long COVID can raise the chances of a child developing type 1 diabetes. And it can even be deadly, leading to multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention describes the syndrome as a "rare but serious condition associated with COVID-19 in which different body parts become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs."

"This study was urgently needed because there are so many questions that need to be answered about pediatric long COVID," Gross says.

The Goodharts hope more attention is given to studying long COVID so more effective treatments can be found. 

    In:
  • COVID-19
  • COVID-19 Pandemic
  • Children

Sara Moniuszko

Sara Moniuszko is a health and lifestyle reporter at CBSNews.com. Previously, she wrote for USA Today, where she was selected to help launch the newspaper's wellness vertical. She now covers breaking and trending news for CBS News' HealthWatch.

author.description: Sara Moniuszko is a health and lifestyle reporter at CBSNews.com. After graduating from George Mason University in 2017 with a double major in Journalism and French, Sara started her journalism career near Washington, D.C. reporting for USA Today's entertainment and travel sections. She then helped launch the newspaper's wellness vertical, covering intersections of culture, mental health and lifestyle trends. She has covered everything from stigma against LGBTQ patients to the latest problematic TikTok trends and has interviewed celebrities from Lady Gaga to Michael Phelps. Now she brings her passion and knowledge of health reporting to CBS News' HealthWatch.

But even months later, his symptoms didn't get better."To see him struggle to stay awake, or crying and saying he doesn't feel good, it's heartbreaking, it's demoralizing, because there's not a lot of treatment options," she told CBS News.Study author Dr. Rachel Gross of NYU's Grossman School of Medicine says one major challenge in tracking the illness is that symptoms can vary."Long COVID can look different in different children, that not everybody has the same symptoms and that it can look different depending on when the symptoms start," she says.Some common long COVID symptoms in kids include:HeadacheLoss of taste and smellBrain fogPainLogan has also been dealing with circulatory and gastrointestinal problems, and he gets tired even from things like standing in line.Adults with long COVID may have these 12 symptoms, study findsDoctors say most children with long COVID recover over several months, but about a third experience symptoms even one year later.Goodhart says it's been frustrating, adding they've tried multiple treatments with only moderate improvement."It's terrible, there's nothing worse than seeing your child go through something you can't fix," she says.The research also shows long COVID can raise the chances of a child developing type 1 diabetes. And it can even be deadly, leading to multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention describes the syndrome as a "rare but serious condition associated with COVID-19 in which different body parts become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs.""This study was urgently needed because there are so many questions that need to be answered about pediatric long COVID," Gross says.The Goodharts hope more attention is given to studying long COVID so more effective treatments can be found.
